citeinfo.origin: California Department of Fish and Game
citeinfo.title: Joshua Tree National Park Vegetation Inventory Project - Field Plot, Accuracy Assessment, Rapid Assessment Points and Quick Plot

descript.abstract: Since the initial vegetation layer created by Aerial Information Systems (AIS) for Joshua Tree National Park (JOTR) in the late 1990's, an accuracy assessment (AA) was conducted during 2007 and 2008, in addition to a rapid assessment (RA) during 2009. The quickplots was also done in 2000 by AIS. Data collected through the AA and RA not only gauged the accuracy of the AIS's aerial photo interpretation but also the initial in-field vegetation key written by JOTR. The AA and RA data was further used in validating changes to both the vegetation layer's attribute information and polygon geometry. This feature class contains spatial information and associated data for all rapid assessment efforts throughout the life of the project (including inital AIS efforts), the quickplots done by AIS, and the accuracy assessment plots that were completed by JOTR staff in 2007-2008.
descript.purpose: Plots points were collected to characterize the vegetation communities, while the accuracy assessment and rapid assessment were collected to aid completion of vegetation mapping in Joshua Tree National Park. The quickplots were collected to describe where only the dominant and most common species.
descript.supplinf: Data were reformatted to match Plots V3.2 and shapefile was imported into a geodatabase by the USGS/CSS/Core Science Analytics and Synthesis.

The burden of determining fitness for use lies with the user.

attracc.attraccr: Accuracy is only as good as the GPS Receiver used.

dataqual.logic: All point features were checked for uniqueness and for correct and complete attributing.
dataqual.complete: All field plots and quickplots collected in 2000 and all AA and RA points required for the accuracy assessment at Joshua Tree National Park are included in this coverage.

horizpa.horizpar: GPS accuracy varies for each plot. Error values were recorded on the AA RA plot form.

srcinfo.srccontr: National Park Service, Aerial Information Systems and California Department of Fish and Game

citeinfo.origin: California Department of Fish and Game
citeinfo.title: JOTR Vegetation Rapid Assessment Assessment Sites

srcinfo.srccontr: JOTR, California Department of Fish and Game and California Native Plant Society

procstep.procdesc: A preliminary classification for the mapping area was developed using the existing California vegetation classification (Sawyer and Keeler–Wolf 1995) in conjunction with the local knowledge of vegetation ecologists at the park that went beyond the recent summary of California's vegetation. The classification was refined to comply with the National Vegetation Classification standards. The working preliminary classification was used to prioritize plot collection and identify preliminary mapping units.

Several overlapping projects were being conducted simultaneously at JOTR during the timeframe of this project, each of which contributed to the overall knowledge of the vegetation patterns in the park. These included three (Watt, Long, and MDEI) separate sets collected specifically for vegetation, using somewhat different methods. Watt Data: In 1996, 108 plots collected, each 100 square meters, were sampled for density, cover, species composition and environmental variables. The Original mapping was done using an on-screen photo interpretation and digitizing method. The plots were chosen using a random, stratified approach from a predetermined grid system throughout the Malapai Hill 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle. This quadrangle was selected as a pilot area because it represented many of the vegetation and topographic features of the park and had the advantage of being relatively accessible by roads. A quantitative classification was developed using this data and was analyzed by the NatureServe regional ecologist Rex Crawford in 1997. The resulting classification and raw plot data were used in this final report as ancillary data to confirm and validate vegetation sampling. However, this data was not taken verbatim as grounds for independently describing vegetation associations. Long Data: In 1997, 74 plots collected, using a 2,100 square meters in Anza-Borrego Desert State Park. The plots were sampled using the protocol described in Keeler-Wolf et al. (1998). This data was analyzed, along with the remainder of the data in 2001, and is among the plots that form the basis of the defined vegetation types. MDEI Data: In 1997, 74 relevé collected, using a 1,000 square meters plot size. This protocol utilized a gradient-directed sampling technique that selected representative combinations of biophysical units throughout the Mojave Desert (Franklin et al. 2002). This data was analyzed, along with the remainder of the data in 2001, and is among the plots that form the basis of the defined vegetation types.
In 1997, 20 plots from a much larger project referred to as the Northeast Colorado Desert vegetation survey completed by California Native Plant Society and California Department of Fish and Game.

Between 2000-2001, AIS collected 300 plots were sampled using the stratified random sampling design, using California Native Plant Society (CNPS) Relevé protocol (CNPS 2004). These plots formed the basis of the park classification and were used to describe the majority of the vegetation types. In summary a total, 576 plots were either directly analyzed or summarized to develop the classification for this project. These included 300 JOTR, 74 Long, 74 MDEI, 108 Watts and 20 NECO samples.

In 2000, AIS collected 24 quick plots were sampled to describe where only the dominant and most common species with their abundance to ensure proper identification of the type, and enough site information to provisionally rank the quality of the occurrence.

1,313 accuracy assessments were conducted in 2007 and 2008. In order to assure that observations can be unambiguously assigned to a map class label, the edge of the circular plot should be far enough away from the polygon edge to eliminate the chance of overlapping the observation plot with a neighboring polygon. The radius of a 0.5 hectare circular plot is approximately 40 meters, whereas the radius of a 0.25 hectare circular plot is approximately 30 meters. To accommodate the placement of the entire observation area of the AA plot within the assigned map class, we used ArcView ® 3.2 to exclude areas within each polygon near boundaries with other map classes. Using the appropriate inference area for each map class, we located individual accuracy assessment center plot positions by allocating the specified number of observation points for each map class to the modified union theme derived from the operations above. This was done using the “Select Random Features” function in the National Park Service Alaskapak tools package for ArcView® 3.2 (NPS 2002). Field observers navigated to the AA point and collect information within a 40 meter or 30 meter radius, depending on the size of the AA plot. Once the observer was familiar with the observational area inside the AA plot, they consulted the JOTR field key and recorded their first call for the vegetation type that most closely represented their observations. If necessary, a second call was recorded when more than one vegetation type represented what they observed. The AA results spurred additional field relevés and a reworking of the map and classification.

In 2009, 111 Rapid assessment plots executed for 14 problematic vegetation associations to complement accuracy assessment data. The goal was to complete a minimum of 10 Rapid Assessments (RA) within the map classes lacking good ecological information (i.e. problematic vegetation types), with a focus on visiting polygons that were not sampled during the AA process, whereas for each of the problematic polygons only one RA was needed. The RA plots are meant to sample the entire stand, or polygon, and the observer chooses a representative spot within the polygon to record their observations. This is contrast to the AA protocols. CDFG were hired to incorporate new data into analysis and make recommendations for updating the classification and map.
Data were reformatted using Plots V3.2, and then the shapefiles and the data was imported into a geodatabase by the USGS/CSS/Core Science Analytics and Synthesis.
